revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Use British English|date=May 2014}} {{infobox road | country = GBR | type = AM | route = 38 | alternate_name = Aston Expressway | maint = [[Birmingham City Council]] | length_mi = 2.0 | direction_a = North | terminus_a = [[Gravelly Hill]] | destinations = [[Birmingham]] | direction_b = South | terminus_b = [[Birmingham]] | established = 1972 | history = Opened and completed: 1972 | counties = [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]] | junction = [[File:UK-Motorway-M6.svg|1000x20px]]
[[M6 motorway]] }} The '''A38(M)''', also known as the '''Aston Expressway''', is a [[motorway]] in [[Birmingham]], England. It is {{convert|2|mi}} long and was opened on 24 May 1972.[http://www.iht.org/motorway/a38mastonstat.htm The Motorway Archive A38(M) – Dates] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311050656/http://www.iht.org/motorway/a38mastonstat.htm |date=11 March 2007 }} It forms part of the much longer [[A38 road|A38]] route. It is extremely unusual among UK motorways, as part of it consists of seven lanes with no central reservation, and operates a [[Reversible lane|tidal flow]] system in an attempt to minimise congestion. Due to the nature of the road, the speed limit is reduced to 50 mph (80 km/h) for most of its length with a very short length of 30 mph (48 km/h),https://www.google.co.uk/maps/@52.4906935,-1.8889903,3a,75y,203.24h,84.6t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sRFkT6PbCktrodePaioHNmA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656 though there are no permanent [[speed camera]]s{{as of?|date=January 2010}}. When construction work of the motorway began in the late 1960s, many late 19th-century and early 20th-century houses in the Aston area had to be demolished to make way for the new route. ==Route== [[File:A38(M) Aston Expressway.jpg|thumb|right|The Aston Expressway approaching [[Birmingham City Centre]]]] A38(M) runs from the [[A5127 road|A5127]] through [[Gravelly Hill Interchange]] where the A38 joins and then shortly after traffic from the [[M6 motorway]] also joins. It then enters a [[Reversible lane|tidal flow]] section. The road is on a [[viaduct]] as it passes through [[Aston]]; this section cuts through the grounds of [[Aston Hall]].[http://www.iht.org/motorway/a38mastonexp.htm The Motorway Archive – A38(M)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311050646/http://www.iht.org/motorway/a38mastonexp.htm |date=11 March 2007 }} The road passes through its first junction after {{convert|1|mi}}. It enters a cutting before reaching the second junction, where the tidal flow ends as does the motorway. The motorway is curved in Aston to avoid an [[Ansells]] [[brewery]]. The motorway was also crossed by a [[vinegar]] [[pipeline transport|pipeline]], carrying the condiment from one part of the since-demolished [[HP Sauce]] factory to the other. ==Tidal flow== The Expressway was the first road in the United Kingdom to introduce [[Reversible lane|tidal flow]] to allow better management of traffic. Lane use is controlled by means of electronic overhead signs, with one lane always closed to create a buffer between the two directions of travel – there is no [[central reservation]]. In the morning, four of the seven lanes are designated for use by traffic heading toward Birmingham city centre, and two lanes for traffic out of the city. In the evening rush hour, this pattern is reversed and four lanes are made available to outbound traffic and two lanes towards the city centre. At all other times, the road runs with three lanes in each direction. [[Motorcycle]]s are banned from the red-surfaced central lane, which contains a drainage channel, regardless of how it is being used. This follows a fatal accident which occurred when one of the drainage covers dislodged.[http://www.cbrd.co.uk/motorway/a38m/ CBRD Motorway Database – A38(M)] ==Junctions== {| border=1 cellpadding=2 style="margin-left:1em; margin-bottom: 1em; color: black; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" |- align="center" bgcolor="0080d0" style="color: white;font-size:120%;" | colspan="3" | A38(M) motorway |- align="center" bgcolor="000000" style="color: white" | Northbound exits | Junction | Southbound exits |- align="center" | ''Road continues to [[Erdington]] as A5127 '' | rowspan="3"| M6 J6
''Gravelly Hill ([[Gravelly Hill Interchange]])''
({{coord|52.511|-1.866|region:GB_type:landmark}}) | ''Start of motorway'' |- align="center" | Lichfield A38 | ''No exit'' |- align="center" | [[Southern England|The SOUTH]], [[Coventry]]
[[Northern England|The NORTH WEST]], [[Wolverhampton]] M6
Aston A5127 | ''No exit'' |- align="center" | ''No exit'' | ''[[List of Road Junctions in the United Kingdom|Park Circus]]''
({{coord|52.5021|-1.8839|region:GB_type:landmark}}) | Aston [[List of B roads in Great Britain|B4132]] |- align="center" | ''Start of motorway'' |rowspan="2"|''[[List of Road Junctions in the United Kingdom|Dartmouth Circus]]''
({{coord|52.4923|-1.8887|region:GB_type:landmark}}) | [[Handsworth, West Midlands|Handsworth]], [[Ladywood]], Aston, [[Small Heath, Birmingham|Small Heath]] [[A4540 road|A4540]]
''(Birmingham Inner Ring Road)'' |-align="center" | Handsworth, Ladywood, Aston, Small Heath A4540
''(Birmingham Inner Ring Road)'' | ''Road continues as A38 to Birmingham City Centre'' |} {{kml}} [[File:Grazebrook Beam Engine.jpg|thumb|right|A [[Boulton and Watt|Boulton & Watt]] [[blowing engine]] re-erected on Dartmouth Circus (at {{coord|52.492537|-1.888189|region:GB_type:landmark}}). It was built in 1817 and used in [[Netherton, West Midlands|Netherton]] at the ironworks of M W Grazebrook.]] The traffic island at Dartmouth Circus houses a preserved [[Boulton and Watt]] steam engine. ==See also== {{commons category|A38(M)}} * [[List of motorways in the United Kingdom]] * [[Transport in Birmingham]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Attached KML|display=inline,title}} * [http://www.cbrd.co.uk/motorway/a38m/ CBRD Motorway Database – A38(M)] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061009150453/http://www.cbrd.co.uk/media/video/a38m.shtml CBRD Videos – A38(M)] * [http://pathetic.org.uk/current/a38m/ Pathetic Motorways – A38(M)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070311050646/http://www.iht.org/motorway/a38mastonexp.htm The Motorway Archive – A38(M)] {{Streets in Birmingham}} {{UK motorways}} {{DEFAULTSORT:3-0038}} [[Category:Motorways in England]] [[Category:Transport in Birmingham, West Midlands]] [[Category:Roads in the West Midlands (county)]] [[Category:Roads with a reversible lane]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox body of water | name = Dragon's Mouths
Bocas del Dragón | other_name = | image = Paria.jpg | alt = | caption = View of the [[Paria Peninsula]] in [[Venezuela]] that is separated from [[Trinidad]] by the waters of '''Boca Grande''', one of the '''Bocas del Dragón''' | image_bathymetry = | alt_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = [[Gulf of Paria]]–[[Caribbean Sea]] ([[Atlantic Ocean]]) | coords = {{coord|10|45|N|61|46|W|source:kolossus-eswiki|display=inline, title}} | type = [[Strait]] | inflow = | outflow = | catchment = | basin_countries = [[Venezuela]]
[[Trinidad and Tobago]] | date-built = | date-flooded = | agency = | length = | width = | area = | depth = | max-depth = | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | frozen = | islands = | cities = | reference = }} The '''Bocas del Dragón''' ('''Dragon's Mouths''') is the name of the series of straits separating the [[Gulf of Paria]] from the [[Caribbean Sea]]. There are four Bocas, from west to east: * The '''Boca Grande''' or '''Grand Boca''' separates [[Chacachacare]] from the [[Paria Peninsula]] and [[Patos Island (Venezuela)|Patos Island]] of [[Venezuela]]. The [[international border]] between [[Trinidad and Tobago]] and Venezuela runs through this strait. * The '''Boca de Navios''' or '''Third Boca''' which separates Chacachacare from [[Huevos]]. * The '''Boca de Huevos''' or '''Second Boca''' which separates Huevos from [[Monos]]. * The '''Boca de Monos''' or '''First Boca''' which separates Monos from the [[Chaguaramas, Trinidad|Chaguaramas]] Peninsula of [[Trinidad]]. The passage was named by Christopher Columbus on his [[Voyages of Christopher Columbus|third voyage]].{{cite book|last1=Williams|first1=Eric|title=History of the People of Trinidad and Tobago|date=1942|publisher=Eworld Inc.|location=Buffalo|isbn=9781617590108|pages=8}} ==Reference== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bocas Del Dragon}} [[Category:Gulf of Paria]] [[Category:Bodies of water of Trinidad and Tobago]] [[Category:International straits]] [[Category:Trinidad and Tobago–Venezuela border]] [[Category:Straits of the Caribbean]] [[Category:Straits of Venezuela]] {{Venezuela-geo-stub}} {{Trinidad-geo-stub}}

revision.text:
[[Image:800px-Slovakia Bratislava 82032-1-.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Part of the Bratislava Riverfront as seen from the [[Lafranconi Bridge]].]]
'''Bratislava Riverfront''' ({{lang-sk|Bratislavské nábrežie}}) is a [[riverfront]] on the river [[Danube]] located on the [[Old Town, Bratislava|Old Town]] side of [[Bratislava]], [[Slovakia]]. It extends from the Karloveská bay near the [[Lafranconi Bridge]] to the [[Port of Bratislava]] and [[Prístavný most|Harbour Bridge]]. In the past, the riverfront included the Coronation Hill, where the newly crowned [[King of Hungary|Kings of Hungary]] would recite an [[oath]] and make crosses with their [[sword]] in four cardinal directions to show their resolution to defend the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20040372/maria-theresas-coronation-re-enacted-in-bratislava.html|title=Maria Theresa’s coronation re-enacted in Bratislava|publisher=The Slovak Spectator|date=4 July 2011|accessdate=25 April 2017}}</ref> The hill was demolished in 1870 when the shores of the Danube were strengthened.
Bratislava Riverfront is a [[tourist attraction]] as well as a leisure area for the citizens of Bratislava.
== Location and division == The [[riverfront]] begins near the garden of the Bratislava Water Company in the [[Karlova Ves]] borough of Bratislava and runs along the [[Danube]] up to the [[Prístavný most|Harbour Bridge]]. It is divided into four sections. * From Karloveská bay to the [[Lafranconi Bridge]]. Named Nábrežie Ľubomíra Kadnára, it consists partially of a [[bike path]] and partially of a narrow dirt road winding through the semi-preserved [[riparian forests]]. The area features the Museum of the Bratislava Water Company, the [[Botanical Garden of the Comenius University]] and the canalised outlet of the river [[Vydrica (river)|Vydrica]]. The area also features a complex of water sports facilities (especially [[kayaking]]) with many local sports clubs present here. * From the [[Lafranconi Bridge]] to the [[Starý most|Old Bridge]]. It consists of the streets Dvořákovo nábrežie, Rázusovo nábrežie and Fajnorovo nábrežie and features a broad walkway with benches, tree alleys and statues. The area includes the Faculty of Physical Education and Sports of the [[Comenius University]], the [[Park kultúry a oddychu]], the [[River Park (Bratislava)|River Park]] complex, the [[Chatam Sofer Memorial]], the Bratislava Passenger Port and many monuments of the [[Old Town, Bratislava|Old Town]] of Bratislava. * From the [[Starý most|Old Bridge]] to the [[Apollo Bridge]]. It consists of the [[Eurovea]] complex and an empty space waiting for the Eurovea Phase 2 construction to begin. It features two artificial pedestrian piers and the culturally protected building of Warehouse No. 7. * From the [[Apollo Bridge]] up to a few dozen meters behind the [[Prístavný most|Harbour Bridge]]. Part of the [[Port of Bratislava]], not officially accessible. It is industrial in character and features numerous protected cultural monuments.
== History == In 2010, a new anti-flood wall was constructed along parts of the riverbank to protect Bratislava from periodic floods on the river [[Danube]]. At the same time, part of the riverbank from the [[Most SNP|New Bridge]] to the Passenger Port was reconstructed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bratislava.sk/nova-tvar-dunajskeho-nabrezia/d-11023583/p1=11050198|title=Nová tvár dunajského nábrežia (New Face of the Danube Riverbank)|publisher=City of Bratislava|date=27 January 2010|accessdate=25 April 2017}}</ref>
== Gallery == <gallery> Image:Bratislava12Slovakia6v.JPG|Part of the Bratislava Riverfront in the [[River Park (Bratislava)|River Park]] complex Image:Bratislava12Slovakia11v.JPG|Part of the Bratislava Riverfront near the [[Most SNP|New Bridge]] Image:Bratislava10Slovakia124.JPG|Part of the Bratislava Riverfront in the [[Eurovea]] complex Image:Slovakia Bratislava 954.jpg|Bratislava Riverfront as seen from [[Petržalka]] Image:Nábrežie.jpg|Historical photograph of the riverfront showing its industrial heritage Image:Sklad cislo 7.jpg|Culturally protected building of Warehouse No. 7 </gallery>
== See also == * [[Geography of Bratislava]] * [[Old Town, Bratislava]]
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox settlement | name = Croatian Littoral | native_name = ''Hrvatsko primorje'' | native_name_lang = hrv | settlement_type = [[Geographic region]] of [[Croatia]]{{smallsup|a}} | image_shield = | shield_size = | image_map = Croatian Littoral.svg | map_caption = Croatian Littoral on a map of Croatia
{{legend inline|#FF0000|Croatian Littoral}}
{{legend inline|#FFAAAA|Sometimes considered part of the Croatian Littoral}} | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = {{flag|Croatia}} | seat_type = Largest city | seat = [[Rijeka]] | area_footnotes = {{smallsup|b}} | area_total_km2 = 2830 | population_footnotes = {{smallsup|b}} | population_total = 228725 | population_as_of = 2011 | population_density_km2 = auto | footnotes = a Croatian Littoral is not designated as an official region; it is a [[geographic region]] only. ----b The figure is an approximation based on the territorial span and population of the municipalities bounded by geographic regions of [[Istria]], [[Mountainous Croatia]], and [[Dalmatia]], including the [[Kvarner Gulf]] islands. }} '''Croatian Littoral''' ({{lang-hr|Hrvatsko primorje}}) is a historical name (period of Austro-Hungarian Monarchy) [[littoral]] for the region of [[Croatia]] comprising mostly Kvarner coastal area between traditional [[Dalmatia]] to the south, [[Mountainous Croatia]] to the north and east, and [[Istria]] and the [[Kvarner Gulf]] of the [[Adriatic Sea]] to the west. The term "Croatian Littoral" developed relatively recently, since the 18th and 19th centuries, reflecting the complex development of Croatia in historical and geographical terms. The term Croatian Littoral is also applied to entire Adriatic coast of modern Croatia in general terms, which is then divided into the [[Dalmatia|Southern Croatian Littoral]] comprising Dalmatia, and the [[Northern Croatian Littoral]] comprising Istria and Croatian Littoral in the strict meaning of the term. Croatian Littoral covers {{convert|2830|km2|abbr=off}} and has a population of 228,725. More than half the region's population lives in the city of [[Rijeka]]—by far the largest urban centre in the area. The foothills of mountains that form the northeast boundary of the region, as well as [[List of islands in the Adriatic|islands]] in the Kvarner Gulf, are a part of the [[Dinaric Alps]], making [[karst]] topography especially prominent in the Croatian Littoral. The Cres – Lošinj and Krk – Rab [[island chain]]s divide the Kvarner Gulf into four distinct areas—[[Rijeka Bay]], Kvarner ([[sensu stricto]]), [[Kvarnerić]], and [[Vinodol Channel]]. The Cres – Lošinj group also includes the inhabited islands of [[Ilovik]], [[Susak]], [[Unije]], [[Vele Srakane]], and [[Male Srakane]], as well as a larger number of small uninhabited islands. [[Zadar Archipelago]] extends to the southeast of the island group. Water significantly contributed to the geomorphology of the area, especially in the [[Bay of Bakar]], a [[ria]] located between Rijeka and [[Kraljevica]]. The most significant inland bodies of water in the region are the {{convert|17.5|km|abbr=off|adj=on}} long [[Rječina]] River and [[Lake Vrana (Cres)|Lake Vrana]] on the island of Cres. The region saw frequent changes to its ruling powers since [[classical antiquity]], including the [[Roman Empire]], the [[Ostrogoths]], the [[Kingdom of the Lombards|Lombards]], the [[Byzantine Empire]], the [[Frankish Empire]], and the [[Kingdom of Croatia (medieval)|Croats]], some of whose major historical heritage originates from the area—most notably the [[Baška tablet]]. The region and adjacent territories became a point of contention between major European powers, including the [[Republic of Venice]], the [[Kingdom of Hungary]], and the [[Habsburg Empire|Habsburg]] and [[Ottoman Empire]]s, as well as [[Austrian Empire|Austria]], the [[First French Empire]], the [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Kingdom of Italy]], and [[Yugoslavia]]. ==Geography== {{see also|Northern Croatian Littoral}} [[File:Kvarnerski zaljev Ucka 0408.jpg|thumb|[[Kvarner Gulf]] shore near [[Rijeka]]]] Croatian Littoral is a [[List of regions of Croatia|geographical region]] of [[Croatia]] comprising the area between [[Dalmatia]] to the south, [[Mountainous Croatia]] to the north and east, and [[Istria]] and the [[Kvarner Gulf]] of the [[Adriatic Sea]] to the west. The region encompasses a large part of [[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County]] and the coastal part of [[Lika-Senj County]]. The island of [[Pag (island)|Pag]] is sometimes included in the region, although it is normally considered to be part of Dalmatia.{{cite journal|journal=Geoadria|publisher=[[University of Zadar]], Croatian Geographic Society|issn=1331-2294|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=84052|author1=Lena Mirošević|author2=Branimir Vukosav|volume=15|issue=1|date=June 2010|pages=81–108|title=Spatial identities of Pag Island and the southern part of the Velebit littoral|accessdate=2 July 2012}} The islands of [[Cres]], [[Lošinj]], [[Krk]], and [[Rab]], as well as further comparatively small nearby islands,{{cite journal|journal=Prilozi Instituta za arheologiju u Zagrebu|publisher=Institute of Archaeology, Zagreb|issn=1330-0644|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=1523|title=Nalazi prapovijesnoga zlata iz Dalmacije i Hrvatskog primorja|language=Croatian|trans-title=Finds of prehistoric gold in Dalmatia and Croatian Littoral|author=Dunja Glogović|pages=27–32|volume=20|issue=1|date=June 2003|accessdate=2 July 2012}} are also considered part of the region, contributing to an alternate name for the region—Kvarner Littoral or Kvarner.{{cite journal|url=http://www.klub-susacana.hr/revija/clanak.asp?Num=68&C=18|journal=Sušačka Revija|issn=1330-1306|publisher=Klub Suščana|issue=68|year=2009|title=Smo Primorci ili ... ?|language=Croatian|trans-title=Are we Primorci or ... ?|accessdate=29 April 2012|author=Branimir Paškvan}} Various definitions exist as to the extent of "Croatian Littoral" and "Kvarner Littoral" as geographical terms. Specifically, Kvarner Littoral is variously considered to extend east to [[Senj]], or even further east.{{cite web|publisher=[[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County]] |url=http://www.pgz.hr/PDF/pgz-povijest.pdf |format=PDF |language=Croatian |title=Povijesni pregled |trans-title=History overview |accessdate=30 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070609182326/http://www.pgz.hr/PDF/pgz-povijest.pdf |archivedate=9 June 2007 |df=dmy }} On the other hand, Kvarner is normally considered to include Istria east of [[Učka]] mountain,{{cite journal|journal=Arhivski vjesnik|publisher=[[Croatian State Archives]]|issn=0570-9008|issue=52|date=November 2009|title=Prilog za bibliografiju objavljenih pravnih izvora (statuta, zakona, urbara i notarskih knjiga) i pravnopovijesnih studija za Istru, kvarnersko primorje i otoke u srednjem i ranom novom vijeku|language=Croatian|author=Ozren Kosanović|pages=129–170|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=73535|trans-title=Contribution to the bibliography of published legal sources (statutes, laws, urbars, and notary books), and related juridico-historical studies for Istria, Kvarner Littoral and its islands in the Middle Ages and Early New Age|accessdate=2 July 2012}} making Kvarner synonymous with the coastal areas and islands of Primorje-Gorski Kotar County.{{cite web|publisher=Croatian Chamber of Commerce |url=http://hgk.biznet.hr/hgk/tekst.php?a=b&page=tekst&id=1004 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060502174414/http://hgk.biznet.hr/hgk/tekst.php?a=b&page=tekst&id=1004 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 May 2006 |title=Turizam |language=Croatian |trans-title=Tourism |accessdate=30 April 2012 |df= }} The term "Croatian Littoral" developed relatively recently, since the 18th and 19th centuries, reflecting the complex development of Croatia in historical and geographical terms. The term is also applied to the entire Adriatic coast of modern Croatia in [[sensu lato|general terms]], which is then divided into the [[Dalmatia|Southern Croatian Littoral]] comprising Dalmatia, and the [[Northern Croatian Littoral]] comprising Istria and Croatian Littoral in the strict meaning of the term. Croatian Littoral covers {{convert|2830|km2|abbr=off}}, has a population of 228,725, and the region as a whole has a population density of {{Pop density|228725|2830|km2|sqmi}}. The islands, encompassing {{convert|1120|km2|abbr=off}}, are home to 39,450 residents.{{cite web|publisher=[[United Nations Development Programme]] in Croatia |url=http://www.licko-senjska.hr/prilika.pdf |format=PDF |language=Croatian |title=(PRI)LIKA! |trans-title=Opportunity/Lika! |year=2009 |accessdate=3 April 2012 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|publisher=[[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County]] |url=http://www.pgz.hr/gradiop.html |language=Croatian |title=Gradovi i općine |trans-title=Cities and municipalities |accessdate=25 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120427164359/http://www.pgz.hr/gradiop.html |archivedate=27 April 2012 |df=dmy }} More than half the region's population lives in the city of [[Rijeka]]—by far the largest urban centre in the area. All other settlements in the region are relatively small, with only four of them exceeding a population of 4,000: [[Crikvenica]], [[Mali Lošinj]] (the largest island settlement), Senj, and [[Kostrena]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dzs.hr/Eng/censuses/census2011/htm/e11_RH.html |title=Census 2011 First Results |publisher=[[Croatian Bureau of Statistics]] |date=29 June 2011 |accessdate=5 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111114150141/http://www.dzs.hr/Eng/censuses/census2011/htm/e11_RH.html |archivedate=14 November 2011 }} {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" cellspacing=2 style="margin-top:7px; margin-right:0px; background:none; text-align:left; font-size:90%;" |- style="font-size:100%; text-align:right;" ! colspan=4|Cities and municipalities of the Croatian Littoral |- style="font-size:100%; text-align:right;" ! |- |align=center style="background:#f0f0f0;" | 1 ||align=left | '''[[Rijeka]]''' ||align=left|[[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County|Primorje-Gorski Kotar]]||127,498||128,735 |- |align=center style="background:#f0f0f0;" | 2 ||align=left | '''[[Crikvenica]]''' ||align=left|Primorje-Gorski Kotar||6,880||11,193 |- |align=center style="background:#f0f0f0;" | 3 ||align=left | '''[[Mali Lošinj]]''' ||align=left|Primorje-Gorski Kotar||5,990||8,070 |- |align=center style="background:#f0f0f0;" | 4 ||align=left | '''[[Senj]]''' ||align=left|[[Lika-Senj County|Lika-Senj]]||4,822||7,165 |- |align=center style="background:#f0f0f0;" | 5 ||align=left | '''[[Kostrena]]''' ||align=left|Primorje-Gorski Kotar||4,158||4,179 |- |colspan="5" align=center style="background:#f5f5f5;"|Sources: [[Croatian Bureau of Statistics]], 2011 Census |} {{clear}} ===Topography and geology=== {{see also|List of islands in the Adriatic|Dinaric Alps}} [[File:Bakarski zaljev-001.jpg|thumb|left|[[Bay of Bakar]]]] The foothills of mountains that form the northeast boundary of the region, as well as [[List of islands in the Adriatic|islands]] in the Kvarner Gulf, are part of the [[Dinaric Alps]], linked to a [[fold and thrust belt]] continuously developing from the Late [[Jurassic]] to recent times. The thrust belt is a part of the [[Alpine orogeny|Alpine]] [[orogeny]] and extends southeast from the southern [[Alps]].{{cite journal|journal=EGU Stephan Mueller Special Publication Series|publisher=[[Copernicus Publications]]|title=Evolution of the northern and western Dinarides: a tectonostratigraphic approach|first=Vlasta|last=Tari-Kovačić|year=2002|pages=223–236|issn=1868-4556|accessdate=3 March 2012|url=http://www.stephan-mueller-spec-publ-ser.net/1/223/2002/smsps-1-223-2002.pdf|format=PDF|issue=1}} [[Geomorphology|Geomorphologically]] the region was formed as the [[Adriatic Plate]] is subducted under structural units comprising the Dinaric Alps. The process formed several [[seismic fault]]s, with most significant among them being the [[Ilirska Bistrica]] – Rijeka – Senj fault, which was the source of several significant earthquakes in past centuries.{{cite journal|journal=Geologia Croatica|issn=1330-030X|publisher=Croatian Geological Survey|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=6366|pages=295–303|title=Seismotectonically Active Zones in the Dinarides|author1=Vlado Kuk|author2=Eduard Prelogović|author3=Ivan Dragičević|volume=53|issue=2|date=December 2000|accessdate=2 July 2012}} The Dinaric Alps in Croatia encompass the regions of [[Gorski Kotar]] and [[Lika]] in the immediate hinterland of the Croatian Littoral, as well as considerable parts of Dalmatia. Their northeastern edge runs from {{convert|1181|m|adj=on}} [[Žumberak]] to the [[Banovina (region)|Banovina region]], along the Sava River,{{cite book|page=195|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aH3ymyEURHoC|title=Encyclopedia of Caves|editor1-first=William B|editor1-last=White|editor2-first=David C|editor2-last=Culver|isbn=978-0-12-383833-9|publisher=Academic Press|year=2012|accessdate=3 March 2012}} and their westernmost landforms are the {{convert|1272|m|adj=on}} [[Ćićarija]] and the {{convert|1396|m|adj=on}} Učka mountains in Istria to the west of the Croatian Littoral region.{{cite journal|publisher=[[Croatian Bureau of Statistics]]|format=PDF|url=http://www.dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/ljetopis/2011/SLJH2011.pdf|journal=Statistical Yearbook of the Republic of Croatia|issn=1333-3305|date=December 2011|volume=43|title=Geographical and Meteorological Data|page=41|accessdate=28 January 2012}} [[Karst]] topography makes up about [[List of karst areas|half of Croatia]] and is especially prominent in the Dinaric Alps and the Croatian Littoral.{{cite web |url=http://www.geografija.hr/clanci/1011/rasirenost-krsa-u-hrvatskoj |title=Raširenost krša u Hrvatskoj |trans-title=Presence of Karst in Croatia |language=Croatian |publisher=Croatian Geographic Society |date=18 December 2006 |author=Mate Matas |accessdate=18 October 2011 |work=geografija.hr |archivedate=8 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69lbXToZS?url=http://www.geografija.hr/clanci/1011/rasirenost-krsa-u-hrvatskoj |df=dmy }} Though most of the soil in the region developed from [[carbonate rock]], [[flysch]] is significantly represented on the Kvarner Gulf coast opposite Krk.{{cite book|pages=146–149|title=Tectonic aspects of the Alpine-Dinaride-Carpathian system|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=864MOs0qeuEC|first=Siegfried|last=Siegesmund|publisher=Geological Society|year=2008|isbn=978-1-86239-252-6|accessdate=3 February 2012}} The karst topography developed from the [[Adriatic Carbonate Platform]], where karstification largely began after the final raising of the [[Dinarides]] in the [[Oligocene]] and [[Miocene]] [[Epoch (geology)|epochs]], when carbonate rock was exposed to atmospheric effects such as rain; this extended to {{convert|120|m}} below the present sea level, exposed during the [[Last Glacial Maximum]]'s sea level drop. It is surmised that some karst formations are related to earlier drops of sea level, most notably the [[Messinian salinity crisis]].{{cite journal|publisher=[[University of Zadar]]|issn=1331-2294|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=14808|journal=Geoadria|title=Submerged Karst – Dead or Alive? Examples from the Eastern Adriatic Coast (Croatia)|first=Maša|last=Surić|pages=5–19|volume=10|issue=1|date=June 2005|accessdate=28 January 2012}} Cres – Lošinj and Krk – Rab [[island chain]]s divide the Kvarner Gulf into four distinct areas: [[Rijeka Bay]], Kvarner ([[sensu stricto]]), [[Kvarnerić]], and [[Vinodol Channel]]. The Cres – Lošinj group also includes the inhabited islands of [[Ilovik]], [[Susak]], [[Unije]], [[Vele Srakane]], and [[Male Srakane]], as well as a larger number of small, uninhabited islands. [[Zadar Archipelago]] extends to the southeast of the island group.{{cite web|publisher=Zadar County Tourist Board |language=Croatian |url=http://www.zadar.hr/page.asp?pageID=27&subID=35 |title=Otoci |trans-title=Islands |accessdate=27 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120506070904/http://www.zadar.hr/page.asp?pageID=27&subID=35 |archivedate=6 May 2012 |df=dmy }} The Krk – Rab island group includes only uninhabited islands in addition to Krk and Rab, the largest among them [[Plavnik]], [[Sveti Grgur]], [[Prvić (Krk)|Prvić]], and [[Goli Otok]]. The Krk – Rab island group is usually thought to represent a single archipelago with the island of Pag (southeast of Rab) and islets surrounding Pag.{{cite journal|journal=Pomorski zbornik|publisher=Društvo za proučavanje i unapređenje pomorstva Republike Hrvatske|issn=0554-6397|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=79698|language=Croatian|volume=44|issue=1|date=May 2006|title=Ranjivost obala u području Kvarnera|trans-title=Vulnerability of Kvarner area shores|author1=Čedomir Benac|author2=Igor Ružić|author3=Elvis Žic|pages=201–214|accessdate=27 April 2012}}{{cite journal|journal=Geologia Croatica|publisher=Croatian Geological Survey|issn=1330-030X|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?id_clanak_jezik=6380&show=clanak|title=Seabed and Surface Sediment Map of the Kvarner Region, Adriatic Sea, Croatia (Lithological Map, 1:500,000)|author1=Mladen Juračić|author2=Čedomir Benac|author3=Ranko Crmarić|volume=52|issue=2|date=December 1999|pages=131–140|accessdate=2 July 2012}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! colspan=6|Data on the populated islands of Croatian Littoral as of 31 March 2001 |- ! scope=col|Island ! scope=col|Population ! scope=col|Area ! scope=col|Highest point ! scope=col|Population

{{Convert|40|m|ft|sortable=on|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=http://www.diver.hr/index2.php?option=com_diver&mode=lokacije&id=6 |title=Cave Srakane |accessdate=10 February 2010 |publisher=DCS Lošinj |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721095601/http://www.diver.hr/index2.php?option=com_diver&mode=lokacije&id=6 |archivedate=21 July 2011 |df=dmy }} | align="right"| {{Convert|3.3|PD/sqkm|PD/acre|sortable=on|abbr=on}} | align="center| {{coord|44|34|N|14|20|E|type:isle_scale:250000|display=inline}} |-class="sortbottom" | colspan=6|Note: All the islands are located in the [[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County]]. |} ===Hydrology and climate=== {{see also|List of rivers of Croatia}} [[File:Vransko jez. na otoku Cresu.jpg|thumb|left|[[Lake Vrana (Cres)|Lake Vrana]] on the island of [[Cres]]]] The availability of water varies significantly throughout the region. The area between Rijeka and [[Vinodol, Croatia|Vinodol]] contains numerous freshwater springs that are largely tapped for water supply systems.{{cite web|publisher=[[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County]] |url=http://www.pgz.hr/eng/zpolozaj.html |title=About the county – geographic location |accessdate=28 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080430091731/http://www.pgz.hr/eng/zpolozaj.html |archivedate=30 April 2008 |df=dmy }} Water significantly contributed to the geomorphology of the area, especially in the [[Bay of Bakar]], a [[ria]] located between Rijeka and [[Kraljevica]].{{cite web|publisher=[[University of Zadar]] |url=http://www.unizd.hr/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=ACOMJkesnos%3D&tabid=1401&mid=3730 |title=Obalna razvedenost – Zaljevi i riječna ušća |language=Croatian |trans-title=Indented coastline – Bays and river confluences |accessdate=28 April 2012 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} At the seaward slopes of [[Velebit]], in areas near Senj and [[Karlobag]], surface watercourses are sparse. They form [[losing stream]]s flowing to the sea, while springs of lower yield dry up during summer.{{cite journal|journal=Senjski zbornik|publisher=Museum of the city of Senj and Senj Museum Society|issn=0582-673X|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=108229|volume=21|issue=1|date=November 1994|title=Temeljna skica geoloških osobina Velebita|language=Croatian|trans-title=Basic outline of geological characteristics of Velebit|author=Andrija Bognar|pages=1–8|accessdate=28 April 2012}} The most significant watercourse in the region is the {{convert|17.5|km|abbr=off|adj=on}} long [[Rječina]] River,{{cite web|publisher=[[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County]] |url=http://www.pgz.hr/rop/dokumenti/ROP%20PGZ%20-%2027-06-2008.pdf |format=PDF |language=Croatian |title=Regionalni operativni program Primorsko-goranske županije 2008.-2013. |trans-title=Regional operative plan of the Primorje-Gorski Kotar County 2008–2013 |accessdate=28 April 2012 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} flowing into the Adriatic Sea in the city of Rijeka.{{cite web|publisher=KD Vodovod i Kanalizacija d.o.o. |url=http://www.kdvik-rijeka.hr/default.asp?ru=8 |title=Grad Rijeka – grad na vodi |trans-title=City of Rijeka – a city at the waterfront |language=Croatian |accessdate=28 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305020613/http://www.kdvik-rijeka.hr/default.asp?ru=8 |archivedate=5 March 2016 |df=dmy }} The islands of Cres, Krk, and Lošinj have significant surface water that is used as the primary water supply source on those islands. The most significant among them is [[Lake Vrana (Cres)|Lake Vrana]] on the island of Cres, containing {{convert|220000000|m3|abbr=off}} of water. The surface of the freshwater lake is at {{convert|16|m|abbr=off}} above sea level, while its maximum depth is {{convert|74|m|abbr=off}}. The Gulf of Kvarner is an especially significant area for the preservation of [[biodiversity]].{{cite web|publisher=Project for Implementation of the Water Framework Directive|url=http://www.wfd-croatia.eu/templates/radnaHrv.asp?sifraStranica=581|title=Geologija – Krš|language=Croatian|trans-title=Geology – Karst|accessdate=3 April 2012}} [[File:Rjecina 040408.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Rječina]] River in [[Rijeka]]]] The Kvarner Gulf islands and the immediate mainland coastal areas enjoy a [[Humid subtropical climate|moderately warm and rainy hot-summer Mediterranean climate]] (Cfa), although the southern part of the Lošinj Island enjoys [[hot-summer Mediterranean climate]] (Csa) as defined by the [[Köppen climate classification]]. Areas of the Croatian Littoral further away from the coast enjoy a moderately warm and rainy [[oceanic climate]] (Cfb), similar to the [[continental climate]] of most inland regions of Croatia.{{cite journal|journal=Geoadria|publisher=[[University of Zadar]], Croatian Geographic Society|issn=1331-2294|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=14843|title=Köppenova podjela klima i hrvatsko nazivlje|language=Croatian|trans-title=Köppen's Classification of Climates and the Croatian Terminology|pages=17–37|volume=8|issue=1|date=June 2003|author1=Tomislav Šegota|author2=Anita Filipčić|accessdate=28 April 2012}} The mean monthly temperature varies throughout the region. On the mainland coast it ranges between {{convert|5.2|°C|°F|lk=on}} (in January) and {{convert|23|°C|°F|lk=on}} (in July). On the Kvarner Gulf islands the mean monthly temperature is somewhat higher; it ranges from {{convert|7.3|°C|°F|lk=on}} (in January) to {{convert|23.8|°C|°F|lk=on}} (in July), while at higher elevations, in the mountains found along the northern and eastern peripheral areas of the region, temperatures range between {{convert|-1.2|°C|°F|lk=on}} (in January) and {{convert|16.8|°C|°F|lk=on}} (in July).{{cite web|url=http://www.kvarner.hr/mediji/osnovni_podaci_o_kvarneru/Geografski_podaci|language=Croatian|title=Geografski podaci|trans-title=Geographic information|publisher=Kvarner tourist board|accessdate=28 April 2012}} The lowest air temperature recorded in the region, {{convert|-16.6|°C|°F|lk=on}}, was measured in Senj, on 10 February 1956.{{cite web|url=http://klima.hr/razno.php?id=priopcenja¶m=apsolutno_najniza|publisher=[[Croatian Meteorological and Hydrological Service]]|language=Croatian|title=Apsolutno najniža temperatura zraka u Hrvatskoj|trans-title=The absolute lowest air temperature in Croatia|date=3 February 2012|accessdate=13 March 2012}} The islands of Lošinj, Cres, Krk, and Rab receive the most sunshine during the year—with 217 clear days per year on average. Seawater temperatures reach up to {{convert|26|°C|°F|lk=on}} in summer, while dipping to {{convert|16|°C|°F|lk=on}} in spring and autumn and as low as {{convert|10|°C|°F|lk=on}} in winter. The predominant winter winds are the [[Bora (wind)|bora]] and [[sirocco]]. The bora is significantly conditioned by wind gaps in the Dinaric Alps bringing cold and dry continental air—the point where it reaches its peak speed is at Senj, with gusts of up to {{convert|180|km/h|kn mph}}. The sirocco brings humid and warm air, often carrying [[Sahara]]n sand that causes [[rain dust]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OFwkVgQNHlsC|title=Physical oceanography of the Adriatic Sea|first1=Benoit|last1=Cushman-Roisin|first2=Miroslav|last2=Gačić|first3=Pierre-Marie |last3=Poulain|isbn=978-1-4020-0225-0|year=2001|publisher=Springer|accessdate=26 January 2012|ref=harv|pages=6–8}} {|class="wikitable" ! colspan=11|Climate characteristics in major cities in Croatian Littoral |- ! rowspan=3|City ! colspan=4|Mean temperature (daily high) ! colspan=6|Mean total rainfall |- ! colspan=2| January ! colspan=2| July ! colspan=3| January ! colspan=3| July |- ! °C ! °F ! °C ! °F ! mm ! in ! days ! mm ! in ! days |-align=center | [[Rijeka]] | {{convert|8.7|C|F|disp=table}} | {{convert|27.7|C|F|disp=table}} | {{convert|134.9|mm|in|disp=table}} | 11.0 | {{convert|82.0|mm|in|disp=table}} | 9.1 |- | colspan=11|Source:[[World Meteorological Organization]]{{cite web|publisher=[[World Meteorological Organization]]|url=http://www.worldweather.org/europe.htm|title=World Weather Information Service|accessdate=27 January 2012}} |- |} ==History== {{see also|History of Croatia}} ===Middle Ages=== [[File:Bascanska ploca.jpg|thumb|[[Baška tablet]] found on [[Krk]] island]] In the [[Early Middle Ages]], after the [[decline of the Roman Empire]], the Adriatic coasts of the region were ruled by [[Ostrogoths]], [[Kingdom of the Lombards|Lombards]], and the [[Byzantine Empire]].{{cite book|pages=326–328|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zt3jZ69vJKQC|title=History of the Lombards|author=[[Paul the Deacon]]|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|year=1974|isbn=978-0-8122-1079-8|accessdate=31 January 2012}}{{cite book|pages=126–130|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dw3FEpOUrRkC|title=A history of the Ostrogoths|first=Thomas S |last=Burns|publisher=Indiana University Press|year=1991|isbn=978-0-253-20600-8|accessdate=31 January 2012}} The [[Carolingian Empire]] arose in the last part of the period and subsequently the [[Kingdom of Italy (medieval)|Frankish Kingdom of Italy]] took control of the Adriatic Sea's western coast extending to the Kvarner Gulf,{{cite book|page=773|title=A history of all nations, from the earliest periods to the present time|first=Samuel Griswold |last=Goodrich|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YU3TAAAAMAAJ|publisher=Miller, Orton & Mulligan|year=1856|accessdate=31 January 2012}} while Byzantine control of the opposite coast gradually shrunk following the [[Avars (Carpathians)|Avar]] and [[Principality of Littoral Croatia|Croatian]] invasions starting in the 7th century.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E_NBAAAAYAAJ|title=Researches on the Danube and the Adriatic|first=Andrew Archibald|last=Paton|year=1861|pages=218–219|publisher=Trübner|accessdate=15 October 2011}} The region was gradually incorporated into the [[Kingdom of Croatia (medieval)|medieval Kingdom of Croatia]] by the 11th century, when the kingdom reached its territorial peak, and the city of Senj became the most important centre of the region. Items of significance to Croatian historical heritage originated from the region in that period. The most notable among them is the [[Baška tablet]], one of the oldest surviving inscriptions in the [[Croatian language]].{{cite journal|journal=Senjski zbornik|publisher=Museum of the city of Senj and Senj Museum Society|issn=0582-673X|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=66945|title=Senjska glagoljska baština|trans-title=Senj glagolitic heritage|language=Croatian|author=Mile Bogović|volume=35|issue=1|date=December 2008|pages=11–26|accessdate=2 July 2012}} The region continued to be contested throughout the [[High Middle Ages]] as the [[Republic of Venice]] started to expand its influence and territory,{{cite book|title=A short history of Byzantium|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FkUmAQAAMAAJ|first=John Julius |last=Norwich|publisher=Knopf|year=1997|isbn=978-0-679-77269-9 |accessdate=31 January 2012|ref=harv|page=72}} gradually pushing back Croatia, which had been in a [[Croatia in personal union with Hungary|personal union of Croatia and Hungary]] since 1102.{{cite journal|journal=Scrinia Slavonica|issn=1332-4853|publisher=Hrvatski institut za povijest – Podružnica za povijest Slavonije, Srijema i Baranje|title= Hrvatsko-ugarski odnosi od sredinjega vijeka do nagodbe iz 1868. s posebnim osvrtom na pitanja Slavonije|trans-title=Croatian-Hungarian relations from the Middle Ages to the Compromise of 1868, with a special survey of the Slavonian issue|language=Croatian|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=68144|author= Ladislav Heka|date=October 2008|volume=8|issue=1|pages=152–173|accessdate=16 October 2011}} By 1420, Venice controlled Istria and Dalmatia, as well as all the Kvarner Gulf islands except Krk. The island became a part of the realm in 1481, but Venice never captured the region's mainland, which would have entirely linked Venetian possessions in the eastern Adriatic.{{cite journal|journal=Povijesni prilozi|publisher=Hrvatski institut za povijest|issn=0351-9767|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=73993|language=Croatian|title=U okrilju Privedre – Mletačka Republika i hrvatski Jadran|trans-title=In Serenissima's realm – Venetian Republic and Croatian Adriatic|author=Lovorka Čoralić|volume=37|issue=37|date=December 2009|pages=11–40|accessdate=29 April 2012}} ===Habsburg era=== [[File:Nehaj Senj Croatia 01.jpg|thumb|left|[[Nehaj Fortress]] near [[Senj]]]] [[Hundred Years' Croatian–Ottoman War|Ottoman conquests]] led to the [[Battle of Krbava field]] (1493) and the [[Battle of Mohács]] (1526), both decisive Ottoman victories, the latter of which caused a succession crisis in the [[Kingdom of Hungary]]. In the [[1527 election in Cetin]], [[Ferdinand I of Habsburg]] was chosen as the new ruler of Croatia, under the condition that he provide protection to Croatia against the Ottoman Empire,{{cite web|url=http://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?sec=404 |title=Povijest saborovanja |trans-title=History of parliamentarism |language=Croatian |publisher=[[Sabor]] |accessdate=18 October 2010 |archivedate=2 December 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202061135/http://www.sabor.hr/Default.aspx?sec=404 |df=dmy }}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lVBB1a0rC70C|author=Richard C. Frucht|title=Eastern Europe: An Introduction to the People, Lands, and Culture|year=2005|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn= 978-1-57607-800-6|accessdate=18 October 2011|pages=422–423}} which had extended as far as Lika in the immediate hinterland of the region since 1522.{{cite journal|journal=Journal – Institute of Croatian History|publisher=Institute of Croatian History, [[University of Zagreb]]|issn=0353-295X|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=76995|language=Croatian|title=Lika i Krbava od Velikog rata za oslobođenje do inkorporacije u Karlovacki generalat (1683–1712)|trans-title=Lika and Krbava since the Great War of Liberation until incorporation in Karlovac general command (1683–1712)|pages=101–110|volume=37|issue=1|date=October 2005|author=Ivan Jurišić|accessdate=2 July 2012}} As the region became a point of contention between the [[Habsburg Empire|Habsburg]]s, Ottomans, and Venetians, its defense was given high importance in the newly established [[Croatian Military Frontier]], as exemplified by the [[Uskoks]] of Senj. After the Ottoman conquest of their original base in [[Klis Fortress|Klis]], the Uskoks established a new headquarters in [[Nehaj Fortress]] as a [[Antemurale myth|bulwark]] against westward expansion by the Ottomans. They also launched raids against Christian communities under Ottoman rule and Venetian commerce and subjects.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5qCDL94HWN8C|title=Religious Warfare in Europe, 1400–1536|author=[[Norman Housley]]|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=2002|isbn=978-0-19-820811-2|pages=14–16|accessdate=29 April 2012}} Increasing conflict between the Uskoks and Venice culminated in 1615 – 1617 [[Uskok War]], which resulted in the resettling of the Uskoks, whose final years in Senj were marked by piracy and looting.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pSxJdE4MYo4C|title=Croatia: A History|author=[[Ivo Goldstein]]|publisher=[[C. Hurst & Co.]]|year=1999|isbn=978-1-85065-525-1|pages=39–40}} Between 1684 and 1689, the Ottomans were forced to retreat from Lika and the entire hinterland of the region. In 1797 the Republic of Venice was abolished after the [[Napoleonic Wars|French conquest]].{{cite book|page=219|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PJEhbcRSELwC|title=Venice reconsidered|first1=John Jeffries |last1=Martin|first2=Dennis|last2=Romano|publisher=[[JHU Press]]|year=2002|isbn=978-0-8018-7308-9|accessdate=1 February 2012}} The Venetian territory was then handed over to the [[Archduchy of Austria]]. The territory was returned to France after the [[Peace of Pressburg (1805)|Peace of Pressburg]] in 1805. However, the former Venetian possessions on the eastern Adriatic shore, including the present-day Croatian Littoral, were joined into a set of separate provinces of the [[First French Empire|French Empire]]: the [[Illyrian Provinces]],{{cite book|pages=192, 245|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PVh4b1_YmskC|title=Europe|publisher=Forgotten Books|isbn=978-1-4400-6217-9|first=H Morse|last=Stephens|year=2010|accessdate=1 February 2012}} created in 1809 through the [[Treaty of Schönbrunn]].{{cite book|pages=188–194|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aW3aMxd5vrkC|title=Napoleon and the transformation of Europe|first=Alexander I|last=Grab|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|year=2003|isbn=978-0-333-68274-6|accessdate=1 February 2012}} Days before the [[Battle of Waterloo]], the [[Congress of Vienna]] awarded the Illyrian Provinces (spanning from the Gulf of [[Trieste#History|Trieste]] to the [[Bay of Kotor]]) to the [[Austrian Empire]].{{cite book|pages=180, 226|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZTC3IWC_py8C|title=The Congress of Vienna|first=Harold |last=Nicolson|publisher=Grove Press|year=2000|isbn=978-0-8021-3744-9|accessdate=1 February 2012}} In 1816 the [[Kingdom of Illyria (1816–1849)|Kingdom of Illyria]]—an Austrian [[crown land#Austria-Hungary|crown land]]—was carved out of the former French possession. The territory originally included [[Duchy of Carinthia|Carinthia]], [[Duchy of Carniola|Carniola]], [[Gorizia and Gradisca]], Trieste, Istria, Rijeka, and [[Civil Croatia]] south of the [[Sava]] River, corresponding to present-day Croatian Littoral and Mountainous Croatia, except the island of Rab.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G9tDboBJ70EC|title=The Land Between: A History of Slovenia|author=[[Oto Luthar]]|publisher=[[Peter Lang (publishing company)]]|year=2008|isbn=978-3-631-57011-1|page=262|accessdate=29 April 2012}} The island and the rest of the former Illyrian Provinces were made a separate crown land, named [[Kingdom of Dalmatia]], in 1817.{{cite journal|journal=Arhivski vjesnik|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=102058&lang=en|publisher=[[Croatian State Archives]]|issn=0570-9008|title=Organizacija uprave u Dalmaciji za vrijeme druge austrijske vladavine 1814–1918|language=Croatian|trans-title=Organisation of administration in Dalmatia during the second Austrian reign 1814–1918|author=Frane Ivković|issue=34–35|date=November 1992|pages=31–51|accessdate=2 July 2012}} Rijeka and Civil Croatia were restored to the Kingdom of Croatia and thus the [[Lands of the Crown of Saint Stephen]] in 1822, reflecting a series of 18th-century royal [[letters patent]] assigning Rijeka to Civil Croatia and the Kingdom of Hungary,{{cite web|publisher=Museum of the city of Rijeka|url=http://muzej-rijeka.hr/rijecka-luka.asp|language=Croatian|title=Riječka luka|trans-title=Port of Rijeka|accessdate=29 April 2012}} giving rise to use of the term "Hungarian Littoral" ({{lang-hu|Magyar partvidék}}).{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OtW2axOSn10C|title=Balkan Economic History, 1550–1950: From Imperial Borderlands to Developing Nations|author1=[[John R. Lampe]]|author2=Marvin R. Jackson|publisher=[[Indiana University Press]]|year=1982|isbn=978-0-253-30368-4|page=72|accessdate=29 April 2012}} Illyria was abolished in 1849 and the crown lands of Carinthia, Carniola, and [[Austrian Littoral]] ({{lang-de|Österreichisches Küstenland}}) were established in its place, with the latter including the Krk and Cres – Lošinj island groups.{{cite web|publisher=[[Miroslav Krleža Lexicographical Institute]]|url=http://enciklopedija.lzmk.hr/clanak.aspx?id=45273|title=Austrijsko primorje|trans-title=Austrian Littoral|language=Croatian|accessdate=29 April 2012}} Through the [[Croatian–Hungarian Settlement]] of 1868 a [[Corpus separatum (Fiume)|corpus separatum]] was formed containing the city of Rijeka, as a territory directly controlled by Hungary.{{cite web|url=http://www.h-net.org/~habsweb/sourcetexts/nagodba1.htm|title=Constitution of Union between Croatia-Slavonia and Hungary|publisher=H-net.org|accessdate=16 May 2010}} In 1881, the military frontier, containing the Senj and Velebit foothills, was absorbed by the [[Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia]].{{cite journal|journal=Zbornik Pravnog fakulteta Sveučilišta u Rijeci|issn=1330-349X|publisher=[[University of Rijeka]]|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=39787|author=Ladislav Heka|title=Hrvatsko-ugarska nagodba u zrcalu tiska|language=Croatian|trans-title=Croatian-Hungarian compromise in light of press clips|volume=28|issue=2|date=December 2007|accessdate=10 April 2012|pages=931–971}}{{cite journal|journal=Politička misao|issn=0032-3241|publisher=[[University of Zagreb]], Faculty of Political Sciences|title=Političko-teritorijalna podjela i opseg civilne Hrvatske u godinama sjedinjenja s vojnom Hrvatskom 1871.-1886.|trans-title=Political and territorial division and scope of civilian Croatia in period of unification with the Croatian military frontier 1871–1886|language=Croatian|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=38709&lang=en|author=Branko Dubravica|pages=159–172|volume=38|issue=3|date=January 2002|accessdate=10 April 2012}} ===20th century=== [[File:Fiume--outlawsdiary00tormuoft.png|thumb|[[Port of Rijeka]] in 1923]] Following World War I, the dissolution of [[Austria-Hungary]], and the [[Treaty of Trianon]], Hungary lost its possessions in the region.{{cite encyclopedia|title=Trianon, Treaty of|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1E1-TrianonTr.html|encyclopedia=[[The Columbia Encyclopedia]]|year=2009}}{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of World War I|last=Tucker|first=Spencer|year=2005|edition=1|page=1183|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2YqjfHLyyj8C&pg=PA1183|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-85109-420-2}} In 1918, a short-lived, unrecognised [[State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs]] was formed out of parts of Austria-Hungary, comprising most of the former monarchy's Adriatic coastline and the entire present-day Croatian Littoral. Later that year, the [[Kingdom of Serbia]] and the State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs formed the [[Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes]]—subsequently renamed to [[Yugoslavia]]. The new union's proponents at the time in the [[Croatian Parliament]] saw the move as a defence against Italian expansionism such as via provisions of the 1915 [[Treaty of London (1915)|Treaty of London]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fqUSGevFe5MC|title=War and revolution in Yugoslavia, 1941–1945|first=Jozo |last=Tomasevich|publisher=Stanford University Press|year=2001|isbn=978-0-8047-3615-2|accessdate=1 February 2012|ref=harv|pages=4–16}} The treaty was largely disregarded by [[United Kingdom|Britain]] and [[French Third Republic|France]] because of conflicting promises made to Serbia and a perceived lack of Italian contribution to the war effort outside [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Italy]] itself.{{cite book|pages=4–16|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PNHxISN-dmQC|title=Italian foreign policy in the interwar period, 1918–1940|first=H James|last=Burgwyn|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=1997|isbn=978-0-275-94877-1|accessdate=1 February 2012}} The 1919 [[Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye (1919)|Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye]] did transfer the Austrian Littoral to Italy, but awarded Dalmatia to Yugoslavia.{{cite book|page=318|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fln44TTgDLIC|title=Europe, 1890–1945|first=Stephen J|last=Lee|publisher=Routledge|year=2003|accessdate=1 February 2012|isbn=978-0-415-25455-7}} Following the war, a [[Gabriele d'Annunzio|private force]] of demobilized Italian soldiers seized Rijeka and set up the [[Italian Regency of Carnaro]]—seen as a harbinger of [[Fascism]]—to force the recognition of Italian claims to the city.{{cite book|pages=127–128|title=Rome in America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U9wNxgCo7ycC|first=Peter R|last=D'Agostino|publisher=University of North Carolina Press|year=2004|isbn=978-0-8078-5515-7|accessdate=1 February 2012}} After sixteen months of the Regency's existence, the [[Treaty of Rapallo (1920)|1920 Treaty of Rapallo]] redefined the Italian–Yugoslav borders, among other things transferring Zadar and the islands of Cres, Lastovo, and [[Palagruža]] to Italy, securing the island of Krk for Yugoslavia, and establishing the [[Free State of Fiume]]; this new state was abolished in 1924 by the [[Treaty of Rome (1924)|Treaty of Rome]] that awarded Rijeka to Italy and [[Sušak, Rijeka|Sušak]] to Yugoslavia.{{cite book|pages=135–137|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qTLSZ3ucaZMC|title=A short history of the Yugoslav peoples|first=Frederick Bernard|last=Singleton|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1985|isbn=978-0-521-27485-2|accessdate=1 February 2012}} In April 1941, [[Invasion of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia was occupied]] by [[Nazi Germany]] and Italy, the latter annexing or occupying the Croatian Littoral, although the [[armistice between Italy and Allied armed forces]] of World War II and the 1947 [[Treaty of Peace with Italy, 1947|Treaty of Peace with Italy]] reversed wartime Italian territorial gains, awarding the entire region and adjacent territory to Yugoslavia and the [[Socialist Republic of Croatia|Federal State of Croatia]].{{cite book|pages=153–156, 198–202|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ORSMBFwjAKcC|author1=Matjaž Klemenčič|author2=Mitja Žagar|title=The former Yugoslavia's diverse peoples: a reference sourcebook|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|year=2004|isbn=978-1-57607-294-3|accessdate=1 February 2012}} After the [[fall of communism]], [[Breakup of Yugoslavia#Secession and War (1991–1992)|Yugoslavia broke apart]] as [[Ten-Day War|Slovenia]] and [[Croatian independence referendum, 1991|Croatia declared independence]] in 1991.{{cite news |newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/world/2-yugoslav-states-vote-independence-to-press-demands.html |title=2 Yugoslav States Vote Independence To Press Demands |author=Chuck Sudetic |date=26 June 1991 |accessdate=12 December 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69Wj75HVR?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/world/2-yugoslav-states-vote-independence-to-press-demands.html |archivedate=29 July 2012 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Although the region suffered an economic decline during the [[Croatian War of Independence]], there was no fighting in the region.{{cite web|publisher=[[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County]]|url=http://www.pgz.hr/docs/pgz2010HR/documents/7/Original.pdf|format=PDF|language=Croatian|title=Povijesni pregled|trans-title=Historical review|year=1997|accessdate=6 January 2013}} ==Culture== {{see also|Culture of Croatia}} [[File:Trsat.jpg|thumb|left|[[Trsat Castle]] in [[Rijeka]]]] Since [[classical antiquity]], the area around Kvarner Bay has been characterized as a meeting point of diverse cultures—from [[Culture of Greece|Hellenic]] and [[Culture of ancient Rome|Roman]] cultures, through the [[Middle Ages]] and a succession of various rulers, to the present day.{{cite web|publisher=Kvarner Tourist Board|url=http://www.kvarner.hr/kultura/english/index.html|title=Cultural heritage on Kvarner|accessdate=21 July 2012}} This blending is reflected in the [[folklore]] of the area, including [[Zvončari]]—bell-ringers best known for annual pageant in [[Kastav]], listed on [[UNESCO]]'s [[Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity]].{{cite web|publisher=[[UNESCO]]|url=http://www.unesco.org/culture/ich/index.php?pg=00011&RL=00243|title=Annual carnival bell ringers' pageant from the Kastav area|accessdate=21 July 2012}} Crossbowmen from Rab are a [[living history]] company [[Historical reenactment|reenacting]] an [[arbalest]] tournament first held in 1364 to commemorate the successful defence of the island using that weapon. A typical decorative motif used in the region is ''morčić'' (plural: ''morčići'')—a dark skinned [[Moors|Moor]] used as a centerpiece on [[jewelry]], usually earrings. Legend has it that the motif is related to a hypothesized battle between Croatian and Ottoman armies on Grobnik north of Rijeka, but it is more likely that it is of Venetian origin, as it is similar to the Venetian ''moretti'' motif, used mostly on brooches and pins.{{cite web|publisher=Kvarner Tourist Board|url=http://www.kvarner.hr/kultura/english/ethnographic.html|title=Ethnographic timeline|author=Mirjana Kos-Nalis|accessdate=21 July 2012}} The earliest architectural heritage of the region includes [[ruins]] of Roman and Byzantine buildings throughout the area and early medieval Croatian burial grounds in the Vinodol area. There are preserved examples of the [[Romanesque architecture]] on the island of Krk, in Vinodol, and in the Kastav area—largely churches, monasteries, and fortifications such as [[Drivenik Castle]]. Several preserved examples of [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] churches exist on the mainland, but during the [[Renaissance]], construction largely consisted of fortifications because of the Ottoman conquest of the hinterland of the region. The most powerful noblemen in the region, the [[House of Zrinski]] and the [[House of Frankopan]], built numerous castles in the area. They include the castles of [[Trsat Castle|Trsat]], Grobnik, [[Bakar]], [[Kraljevica]], Ledenice, [[Bribir, Primorje-Gorski Kotar County|Bribir]], [[Hreljin Castle|Hreljin]], [[Grižane Castle|Grižane]], Novi Vinodolski, [[Krk (town)|Krk]], Drivenik and Gradec near [[Vrbnik]]. The most representative piece of [[Baroque architecture]] is the [[Rijeka Cathedral|St. Vitus Cathedral]] in Rijeka.{{cite web|publisher=Kvarner Tourist Board|url=http://www.kvarner.hr/kultura/english/architectural.html|title=Architectural heritage|author1=Marijan Bradanović|author2=Daina Glavočić|accessdate=21 July 2012}} The region was birthplace or home to several writers who made their marks in [[Croatian literature|Croatian]], [[Italian literature|Italian]], and [[Austrian literature]]. These include [[Ivan Mažuranić]]—one of the foremost authors of Croatian literature in the first half of the 19th century—[[Janko Polić Kamov]], [[Ödön von Horváth]], and many others. [[Chakavian dialect]], spoken in the region, is widely present in the works of poets born or living in the region.{{cite web|publisher=Kvarner Tourist Board|url=http://www.kvarner.hr/kultura/english/literature.html|title=A reader's guide to Kvarner|author=Velid Đekić|accessdate=21 July 2012}} The most significant artist from the region is [[Juraj Julije Klović]] ({{lang-it|Giorgio Giulio Clovio}})—a 16th-century [[miniaturist]], [[Illuminated manuscript|illuminator]], and artist born in [[Grižane-Belgrad|Grižane]] in Vinodol. 20th-century artists born or active in the region are [[Romolo Venucci]], [[Jakov Smokvina]], [[Vladimir Udatny]], [[Antun Haller]], [[Ivo Kalina]], [[Vjekoslav Vojo Radoičić]], and many others. Churches and monasteries in the region treasure a great number of works of art. These include a 1535 altar [[polyptych]] by [[Girolamo da Santacroce]] in the [[Franciscan]] monastery on [[Košljun]] island, while a [[Paolo Veneziano]] polyptych from [[Order of Saint Benedict|Benedictine]] abbey in [[Jurandvor]] near [[Baška]] is in the collection of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Krk]].{{cite web|publisher=Kvarner Tourist Board|url=http://www.kvarner.hr/kultura/english/visual.html|title=A panoramic survey of visual arts|author=Nataša Šegota Lah|accessdate=21 July 2012}} ==Economy== {{see also|Economy of Croatia}} [[File:Kraljevica 2010 0728 02.JPG|thumb|left|[[INA (company)|INA]] [[oil refinery]] in [[Urinj]] near [[Rijeka]]]] The economy of the Croatian Littoral is largely centered on the city of Rijeka, whose economic impact is felt directly not only in the geographic region, but also in other parts of Primorje-Gorski Kotar County—[[Gorski Kotar]] and [[Liburnia (modern region)]]—and a substantial part of Lika-Senj County.{{cite web|url=http://web.efzg.hr/dok/MGR/iraguz/3%20-%20Studija%20o%20utjecaju%20na%20turizam%20projekta%20_Družba%20Adria_.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=[[Faculty of Economics and Business, University of Zagreb]] |language=Croatian |title=Studija o utjecaju na okoliš projekta "Družba Adria" |trans-title=Environmental impact assessment for the "Druzhba Adria" project |location=[[Zagreb]] |date=May 2004 |author=Boris Pirjevec |accessdate=29 June 2012 |display-authors=etal }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The most significant economic activities in the Primorje-Gorski Kotar County are transport, largely based on activities of the [[Port of Rijeka]], [[shipbuilding]] and tourism in the coastal areas representing a part of the Northern Croatian Littoral, and [[forestry]] and [[wood processing]] in the Gorski Kotar region in the hinterland.{{cite web|publisher=[[Croatian Chamber of Economy]]|url=http://www.hgk.hr/wps/portal/!ut/p/.cmd/cl/_th/J_3_CH/_s.7_0_A/7_0_PP/.l/hr?legacyWcmClippingUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fhgk.biznet.hr%2Fhgk%2Ftekst3.php%3Fa%3Db%26page%3Dtekst%26id%3D899%26kid%3D1340|language=Croatian|title=Gospodarski profil županije|trans-title=Economic profile of the county|accessdate=30 June 2012}} In the city of Rijeka itself, the most significant economic activities are [[civil engineering]], [[wholesale]] and [[retail]] trade, transport and storage services, and the [[processing industry]].{{cite web|publisher=[[Rijeka|City of Rijeka]] |url=http://www.rijeka.hr/RijeckoGospodarstvoTrendovi |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130217161008/http://www.rijeka.hr/RijeckoGospodarstvoTrendovi |dead-url=yes |archive-date=17 February 2013 |language=Croatian |title=Riječko gospodarstvo – trendovi i perspektive |trans-title=Economy of Rijeka – trends and the future |accessdate=30 June 2012 }} Tourism, wood processing, and agriculture are the predominant economic activities in Lika-Senj County, where nearly all businesses are [[small and medium enterprises]]s.{{cite web|publisher=[[Croatian Chamber of Economy]]|url=http://www.hgk.hr/wps/portal/!ut/p/.cmd/cl/_th/J_3_CH/_s.7_0_A/7_0_PM/.l/hr?legacyWcmClippingUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fhgk.biznet.hr%2Fhgk%2Ftekst3.php%3Fa%3Db%26page%3Dtekst%26id%3D1009%26kid%3D708|language=Croatian|title=Gospodarski profil županije|trans-title=Economic profile of the county|accessdate=30 June 2012}} [[File:Cres marina.jpg|thumb|[[Marina]]s contribute significantly to the region's tourist industry.{{cite news|newspaper=[[Novi list]]|url=http://www.novilist.hr/Lifestyle/Nautika/Talijanski-jahtasi-sele-se-u-hrvatske-marine|language=Croatian|title=Talijanski jahtaši sele se u hrvatske marine|trans-title=Italian yachts move to Croatia|date=13 December 2011|author=Ana Raić Knežević|accessdate=30 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212034226/http://www.novilist.hr/Lifestyle/Nautika/Talijanski-jahtasi-sele-se-u-hrvatske-marine|archivedate=12 February 2012|df=dmy-all}}]] In 2010, two companies headquartered in the Croatian Littoral ranked among the top fifty among [[List of companies of Croatia|Croatian companies]] by [[operating income]]. The highest ranked among them was the Rijeka-based [[Plodine]] [[supermarket chain]], which ranked 16th,{{cite web|publisher=Plodine |url=http://www.plodine.hr/o-nama-1.html?PHPSESSID=286f044bb04d5ca142e30a6e7622b565 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130217192719/http://www.plodine.hr/o-nama-1.html?PHPSESSID=286f044bb04d5ca142e30a6e7622b565 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=17 February 2013 |title=O nama |language=Croatian |trans-title=About us |accessdate=30 June 2012 }} and [[Euro Petrol]], a [[petroleum product]] wholesale and retail company,{{cite web|publisher=Euro Petrol |title=O nama |trans-title=About us |language=Croatian |url=http://www.europetrol.hr/onama.htm |accessdate=30 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606182400/http://www.europetrol.hr/onama.htm |archivedate=6 June 2012 |df=dmy }} which ranked 22nd.{{cite journal|journal=[[Privredni vjesnik]]|url=http://issuu.com/nestar/docs/400naj2010|pages=38–50|title=Rang-ljestvica 400 najvećih|language=Croatian|trans-title=Ranking of the top 400|date=July 2011|publisher=[[Croatian Chamber of Economy]]|volume=58|issue=3687|accessdate=17 June 2012}} {| class="wikitable" cellspacing=2 style="margin-top:7px; margin-right:0px; background:none; text-align:left; font-size:90%;" |- style="font-size:100%; text-align:right;" ! rowspan=2|[[Counties of Croatia|County]] !! colspan=2|[[GDP]] !! colspan=2|[[GDP per capita]] |- ! million [[euro|€]] || Index
(Croatia=100) || € || Index
(Croatia=100) |- | [[Lika-Senj County|Lika-Senj]] || style="text-align:right;padding-right:2px"|435|| style="text-align:right;padding-right:2px"|1.0|| style="text-align:right;padding-right:2px"|8,707|| style="text-align:right;padding-right:2px"|86.1 |- | [[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County|Primorje-Gorski Kotar]] || style="text-align:right;padding-right:2px"|3,744|| style="text-align:right;padding-right:2px"|8.4|| style="text-align:right;padding-right:2px"|12,305|| style="text-align:right;padding-right:2px"|121.7 |- ! TOTAL: || style="text-align:right;padding-right:2px"|4,179|| style="text-align:right;padding-right:2px"|9.4|| style="text-align:right;padding-right:2px"|12,038|| style="text-align:right;padding-right:2px"|119.1 |- | colspan=5|Source: [[Croatian Bureau of Statistics]] (2008 data){{cite web|publisher=[[Croatian Bureau of Statistics]]|url=http://www.dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/publication/2011/12-01-02_01_2011.htm|title=Gross domestic product for Republic of Croatia, statistical regions at level 2 and counties, 2008|date=11 February 2011|accessdate=29 March 2012}} |} ===Infrastructure=== [[File:Luka brajdica 040408.jpg|thumb|right|[[Port of Rijeka]] container cargo terminal]] {{see also|Transport in Croatia}} [[Pan-European corridors|Pan-European transport corridor branch Vb]] runs through the Croatian Littoral region. The route encompasses the [[A6 (Croatia)|A6 motorway]] spanning from the [[Orehovica interchange]]—part of the [[Rijeka bypass]] where the A6 and the [[A7 (Croatia)|A7 motorways]] meet—to the [[Bosiljevo 2 interchange]], where the corridor route switches to the [[A1 (Croatia)|A1 motorway]] before proceeding north to [[Zagreb]] and [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]]. The corridor also comprises a railway line connecting the [[Port of Rijeka]] to Zagreb and further destinations abroad.{{cite web |publisher=[[European Union]] |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-02-1275_en.htm?locale=en |title=Transport : launch of the Italy-Turkey pan-European Corridor through Albania, Bulgaria, Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Greece |date=9 September 2002 |accessdate=6 September 2010 |archivedate=5 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DS67i2iy?url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-02-1275_en.htm?locale=en |deadurl=yes |df= }} Another significant road transport route in the region is the A7 motorway, connecting Rijeka to [[Slovenia]].{{cite news | newspaper = [[Narodne novine]] | language = Croatian | url = http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/305463.html | title = Pravilnik o označavanju autocesta, njihove stacionaže, brojeva izlaza i prometnih čvorišta te naziva izlaza, prometnih čvorišta i odmorišta |trans-title=Regulation on motorway markings, chainage, interchange/exit/service area numbers and names | date = 6 May 2003 | accessdate=14 September 2011}} The island of Krk is connected to the mainland via the [[Krk Bridge]]—comprising a {{convert|390|m|adj=on}} reinforced concrete arch, the longest in the world when completed in 1980.{{cite journal|journal=Građevinar|publisher=Croatian association of civil engineers|issn=0350-2465|title=Dvadeseta obljetnica mosta kopno – otok Krk|language=Croatian|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=20030&lang=en|trans-title=Twentieth anniversary of the Krk – mainland bridge|author=Veselin Simović|volume=52|issue=8|date=September 2000|pages=431–442|accessdate=22 July 2012}} The Port of Rijeka is the largest port in Croatia, handling the greatest portion of the country's imports and exports.{{cite web|publisher=[[World Bank]]|language= Croatian| title= Riječka luka –jadranski "prolaz" prema Europi|trans-title=The Port of Rijeka – Adriatic "gateway" to Europe| date= 3 March 2006| accessdate=13 October 2011| url= http://go.worldbank.org/V9N60RX7L0}}{{cite journal| author1= Čedomir Dundović| author2= Bojan Hlača| title= New Concept of the Container Terminal in the Port of Rijeka| journal=Pomorstvo| year= 2007| volume= 21| issue= 2| url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=29666| pages= 51–68| issn= 1332-0718| publisher=[[University of Rijeka|University of Rijeka, Faculty of Maritime Studies]]|accessdate=2 July 2012}} Its facilities include terminals and other structures in the city and in the area reaching from the [[Bay of Bakar]], where the bulk cargo terminal is located, approximately {{convert|13|km|abbr=off}} east of Rijeka, to Bršica to the west of Rijeka, where there is a multi-purpose terminal.{{cite web|publisher=Luka Rijeka d.d.|url= http://www.lukarijeka.hr/en/terminals/default.aspx |title= Terminals |accessdate=23 August 2011}} The Port of Rijeka also serves passenger and ferry lines operated by [[Jadrolinija]] to the nearby islands of Cres, Mali Lošinj, Susak, Ilovik, Unije, Rab, and Pag, as well as to Adriatic ports further south, such as [[Split (city)|Split]] and [[Dubrovnik]]. The line to Split and Dubrovnik also serves the islands of [[Hvar]], [[Korčula]], and [[Mljet]].{{cite web| publisher=[[Jadrolinija]]| title= TABULAR PRESENTATION OF THE TIMETABLE FROM 01.01.2011 TILL 31 December 2011| url= http://www.jadrolinija.hr/default.aspx?dpid=1522| accessdate=24 August 2011}}{{cite web|publisher=Agencija za obalni linijski pomorski promet |url=http://www.agencija-zolpp.hr/Brodskelinije/tabid/1267/Default.aspx |language=Croatian |title=Plovidbeni red za 2011. godinu |trans-title=Sailing Schedule for Year 2011 |accessdate=27 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110902234646/http://www.agencija-zolpp.hr/Brodskelinije/tabid/1267/Default.aspx |archivedate=2 September 2011 |df=dmy }} There are two [[international airport]]s in the region—[[Rijeka Airport|Rijeka]] and [[Lošinj Airport|Lošinj]].{{cite web|publisher=Croatian Civil Aviation Agency|format=PDF|url=http://www.ccaa.hr/UserDocsImages/dokumenti/926/Tablica%20aerodroma_za%20objavu_02052012.pdf|language=Croatian|title=Popis registriranih aerodroma u Republici Hrvatskoj|trans-title=List of registered airports in the Republic of Croatia|date=2 May 2012|accessdate=30 June 2012}} Both of the airports serve few flights, but the Rijeka Airport is busier of the two.{{cite journal|journal=Priopćenje Državnog zavoda za statistiku Republike Hrvatske|issn=1330-0350|publisher=[[Croatian Bureau of Statistics]]|url=http://www.dzs.hr/Hrv_Eng/publication/2011/05-01-05_07_2011.htm|title=Promet u zračnim lukama u srpnju 2011.|trans-title=Airport traffic in July 2011|language=Croatian|date=9 September 2011|volume=48|issue=5.1.5/7.|accessdate=30 June 2012}} [[Pipeline transport]] infrastructure in the region comprises the [[Jadranski naftovod]] (JANAF) pipeline connecting the [[Omišalj]] [[oil terminal]]—a part of the Port of Rijeka—to [[Sisak]] and [[Virje]] [[crude oil]] storage facilities and terminals and to a terminal in [[Slavonski Brod]] further east on the Sava River.{{cite web|publisher=[[Jadranski naftovod]]|url=http://www.janaf.hr/oil-pipeline/the-janaf-system/|title=The JANAF system|accessdate=27 June 2012}} JANAF also operates a pipeline between the terminal and the [[INA (company)|INA's]] [[Rijeka Refinery]].{{cite web|publisher=limun.hr|url=http://limun.hr/main.aspx?id=554073|language=Croatian|title=Iskrcavanje nafte na Urinju prijeti Kvarneru|trans-title=Transshipment of oil at Urinj threatens Kvarner|date=3 February 2010|accessdate=30 June 2012}} ==See also== {{portal|Croatia}} *[[Geography of Croatia]] *[[Liburnia]] {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]] maps ** Kvarner and Adjacent Waters article}} [[Category:Geography of Croatia]]
